title: Understanding the Function
text: The function we are looking at is $$`f(x)=\frac{\sqrt{x+4}}{x-4}`$$. Remember, a function is just a way to make something else from our input `x`.

title: Domains and Restrictions
text: The domain of a function is the set of all possible input values $$(x-values)$$ that we can plug into the function without causing any issues. Here, we're dealing with square roots and denominators, both of which have specific restrictions.

title: Square Root Considerations
text: For square roots, the expression under the square root (called the radicand) must be greater than or equal to zero. So for $$`\sqrt{x+4}`$$, the radicand $$`x+4`$$ must be greater than or equal to $$0$$. What does that tell you about `x`?

title: Solving Radicand Inequality
text: Let's solve the inequality $$`x+4 \geq 0`$$. Subtract $$4$$ from both sides to find the range of possible `x`.

title: Denominator Restrictions
text: For fractions, the denominator (bottom part of the fraction) cannot be zero because division by zero is undefined. In $$`f(x)=\frac{\sqrt{x+4}}{x-4}`$$, what does this tell us about `x-4`?

title: Solving Denominator Restriction
text: Set the denominator not equal to zero: $$`x-4 \neq 0`$$. Solve this equation to find what `x` cannot be. Please enter your answer as $$x \neq a$$ where a is the solution to the equation.

title: Combining Conditions for Domain
text: Now, we have two results: $$`x \geq -4`$$ from the square root and $$`x \neq 4`$$ from the denominator. How can we combine these into one statement for the domain of the function?

title: Final Domain in Interval Notation
text: Interpret the results in interval notation by considering that `x` is greater than or equal to `-4` but cannot be `4`.
